status_message:
Mark Ruskell today used Topical Questions at Holyrood to challenge Scottish Ministers over their lack of action on the growing problem of air pollution from traffic.

The most polluted zones include Bearsden, Glasgow, Johnstone, Coatbridge, Crieff, Cambuslang, Linlithgow, Edinburgh, Musselburgh, Falkirk, Dunfermline, Dundee, Perth, Aberdeen and Inverness.

"Legally, the buck stops with the Scottish Government - they need to commit to making Low Emission Zones happen or face the consequences of inaction in the courts."

https://greens.scot/news/growing-problem-of-air-pollution-is-a-public-health-crisis

status_message:
A report for the Scottish Greens published today shows how more low-carbon power could be generated for less money by devolving control over Scottish consumers' electricity bills.

Across the UK, electricity consumers are set to pay around £16 a year for 35 years for the UK government's new nuclear plant at Hinkley Point in Somerset, but analysis shows that for the same amount, Scots could fund almost twice as much power from onshore and offshore wind farms.

https://greens.scot/news/energy-report-for-greens-shows-how-to-double-our-power
link_name: Energy: Report for Greens shows how to double our power

status_message:

status_message:
Coverage in today's Daily Record for Alison Johnstone's motion on the Stop PIP campaign. 

Alison said:

"The Record are to be applauded for highlighting the appalling treatment of vulnerable people who are assessed for PIP. Denial or withdrawal of PIP simply does not help people and the devolution of this aspect of the social security system can't come soon enough.
 
"Assessments are stressful and undignified, with claimants viewed as guilty until proven innocent. Repeat assessments for people with chronic or degenerative illnesses should clearly be abolished. The whole PIP process needs reviewed so we can restore humanity to our social security system.
 
"Greens have succeeded in persuading SNP Ministers to make devolved employment programmes voluntary so the DWP's cruel sanctions regime won't apply. The devolution of powers gives Scotland many such opportunities to adopt a fairer approach."

See which MSPs have signed the motion, here: http://www.parliament.scot/parliamentarybusiness/28877.aspx?SearchType=Advance&ReferenceNumbers=S5M-02528&ResultsPerPage=10
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Patrick is welcoming comments by economic experts on the creation of new income tax bands to raise revenues for public services.

Speaking at Holyrood's Finance Committee, David Bell, Professor of Economics at the University of Stirling, suggested opting for a "Scandinavian solution", where additional tax bands are created between the current 20p basic rate and the higher 40p rate, to generate additional funds.

This approach was advocated by the Scottish Greens in the 2016 election paper: Fair Funding For Public Services.

status_message:
Today we woke up to the awful news that Scotland faces being dragged out of the European Union against our democratic will.

Our petition to Keep Scotland IN Europe has over 25,000 signatures in just one day. 

Sign, share and spread the word; Scotland wants to stay. 

https://greens.scot/keep-scotland-in-europe
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Scotland looks set to leave the European Union, but not by choice.

We voted to Remain and in big numbers, but it wasn't enough to outweigh votes in the rest of the UK seeking to drag Scotland out of the EU.

It's not over though. Scottish Greens are calling on Holyrood to examine and exhaust every option for continuing Scotland's close ties with Europe.

Join us today in making that call. Like and Share.
link_name: Dear Holyrood keep Scotland in Europe

status_message:
Scotland's youngest MSP Ross Greer on why young people should vote remain today - 

"When the UK government is quite happy to see the youngest workers exploited by zero-hours contracts, poverty pay and poor conditions, it is the EU which guarantees us all some significant rights – to a minimum amount of annual leave, ending dangerous hours & overwork and safety regulations which have reduced workplace deaths by over two thirds.

Such measures are unlikely to survive if we give Westminster full control. UK Governments have a history of trying to block such progressive steps."

Read - https://greens.scot/blog/young-people-in-scotland-must-be-part-of-building-a-better-europe

status_message:
"I was debating with people arguing a left case for leaving the EU. I can understand some of where they're coming from, though I fail to see any progressive vision of where leaving the EU will take us. What I find most bemusing is that there seems to be no recognition that the circumstance and climate that a vote to leave would be taken in, would be a clear win for the right, and pave the way for a far harsher version of intolerance and turbo capitalism than we have now, with diminishing rights and protection for workers."

Zara Kitson blogs - https://greens.scot/blog/heres-to-our-future-and-to-love-and-respect-winning-over-hate%E2%80%8B
link_name: Here's to our future, and to love and respect winning over hate.

status_message:
As a mark of respect for Jo Cox MP, we have chosen to suspend campaigning on Saturday. This means that we will not be holding any events or street stalls. 

In the wake of such a horrific event, we turn to the words of Jo's husband Brendan who asked that "…we all unite to fight against the hatred that killed her. Hate doesn't have a creed, race or religion, it is poisonous."

Instead, we fight hate with love.
Earlier this week our education spokesperson Ross Greer spoke in a Holyrood debate on colleges and universities. Catch up with what he had to say...
link_name: Voices of students and staff must be at heart of education debate

status_message:
Good to see the First Minister adopting a Green manifesto proposal: a young carer's grant.

"During the election campaign the Scottish Greens emphasised the need to value the role of carers in our society. We proposed using new devolved powers over the Carer's Allowance to increase payments by 50 per cent to £93 a week. It's good to see the First Minister at least committing to increasing the allowance and Greens will continue to advocate a meaningful increase. The adoption of our policy on young carers and student carers in need of financial support is very welcome and we look forward to that idea coming to fruition."

Read a fuller response from Patrick Harvie to today's statement by the FM here:

https://greens.scot/news/adoption-of-our-policy-on-young-carers-is-welcome

status_message:
We welcome today's cabinet reshuffle by the First Minister, noting that Fergus Ewing has been moved away from the energy brief and that the government's emphasis on education policy has been signalled by the appointment of John Swinney.  

"The Green group of MSPs looks forward to working constructively with the new ministerial team in the months and years ahead, but we will not hold back where robust debate is needed," says Patrick Harvie.

Read more here:

https://greens.scot/news/cabinet-reshuffle-suggests-fm-understands-need-to-reach-out-to-others
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
New research shows a continued downward trend in people finding it easy to see a doctor. 

It also shows carers are concerned that their responsibilities are having a negative impact on their health and wellbeing.

The findings must prompt bold action by ministers, says Alison Johnstone MSP, Health spokesperson for the Scottish Greens.

Read more here:

https://greens.scot/news/survey-shows-need-to-pick-up-pace-on-investment-in-general-practice
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
"I congratulate Nicola Sturgeon on her election as First Minister and the Green group of MSPs looks forward to engaging with her government in the months and years ahead. The SNP losing its majority opens up an opportunity for Holyrood to develop creative, collaborative solutions to the challenges in our economy and our society." 

Read more from Patrick Harvie here:

https://greens.scot/news/minority-government-is-opportunity-to-develop-creative-solutions-to-challenges
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
A very welcome card sent to the campaign office this week:

"I am a SNP member, but have already voted by post for your party on the regional list, convinced that my party must be heavily pressured to adopt a far more radical stance, especially in the matter of land reform. Please accept herewith a contribution equal to that I have already made to the SNP."

With just 7 days to go, momentum for a bolder Holyrood has reached an all time high. The polls are looking promising and our ground campaign is bigger than ever before. Thanks for being part of it!

status_message:
We're stepping up our campaign for bolder action on tax dodgers, derelict land and farming tenancies as the Land Reform Bill heads for a final vote in parliament tomorrow (Wednesday).

Today, Andy Wightman, land reform spokesperson for the Scottish Greens and MSP candidate for Lothian, has published a blog revealing that companies owned by the Buccleuch Estates use tax havens in the Cayman Islands.

Tomorrow, Patrick Harvie, Scottish Green MSP for Glasgow, will press amendments to the Bill to restrict ownership by companies using British Overseas Territories and Crown Dependencies such as the Cayman Islands. He will also press an amendment aimed at giving local authorities the ability to tax vacant or derelict land.

Alison Johnstone, Scottish Green MSP for Lothian, will press an amendment aimed at supporting tenant farmers. The SNP has promised a consultation; Alison's amendment will force ministers to outline a timescale for this.

Read more here:

https://greens.scot/news/scottish-land-should-not-be-owned-by-companies-using-tax-havens
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Liberal Democrats can't seem to be able to make up their mind on fracking. Our position is clear - both Scottish Green Party members and leadership want a full, permanent ban.

Patrick Harvie said: 

"The Liberal Democrats are all over the place on this issue. First they gave fracking the green light when they ran the UK Government's energy department, then they wanted a ban, then they didn't, and now their Scottish leadership is going against members' democratic vote.

"The Scottish Greens take pride in being a democratic party, and both our membership and leadership are united in demanding a full ban on fracking and unconventional gas. We will continue to call for a ban and to hold the SNP to account in the next Parliament."

https://greens.scot/news/greens-will-continue-to-lead-campaign-against-fracking-1

A YouGov poll for Scottish Renewables shows that 70 per cent of Scots want to see more renewable energy in Scotland, while two thirds want to see the Scottish Government bring in policies to tackle greenhouse gas emissions and climate change.

"Scottish Greens have consistently championed the development of the renewables industry and we have led the calls for investment in a skills transition from oil and gas. We have pushed hard for the Scottish Government to open up more community and public ownership of wind, hydro and solar schemes." says Patrick Harvie MSP.

https://greens.scot/news/scotland-can-be-greener-in-how-it-produces-and-consumes-energy

status_message:
Our MSPs will use today's Holyrood debate on the 2016-17 Budget to push the Scottish Government to be bolder in enabling local authorities to raise vital revenue to protect frontline services.

We've been challenging the Government throughout the current Parliament to find progressive ways of raising revenue, and have put forward specific proposals for doing so:

-Taxing derelict and vacant land.
-Allowing local authorities to decide their own levels of Council Tax without financial penalty.
-Adjusting the Council Tax multiplier to reduce tax for lower band properties and increase it for undertaxed higher band properties.

Read more here:

https://greens.scot/news/budget-greens-push-government-to-be-bold-on-local-finance
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
With our candidates Maggie Chapman and Sarah Beattie-Smith speaking at the Radical Independence conference today, we're reaffirming our commitment to a second #indyref when the people of Scotland call for one. #RIC2016

We state that:

1. The Scottish Green Party, which is committed to making popular democracy a reality at the national, regional and local level, believes that there should in time be a second referendum on Scottish independence.

2. In that referendum the Scottish Greens will campaign for independence to secure the powers needed for a socially just and sustainable Scotland.

3. The timing of the referendum should be determined by public appetite: Scotland should decide, when Scotland wants to decide.

4. In assessing public appetite for a second referendum we will respect new kinds of citizen-led initiatives - for example, a call for a referendum signed by up to 1 million people on the electoral register.

5. For the next term of the Scottish Parliament Green MSPs will focus on using existing and forthcoming powers to deliver the changes that will make a difference to the people of Scotland - on fuel poverty, land reform, funding public services and many other challenges which need to be tackled right now.

6. We will continue to call for further powers being devolved to the Scottish Parliament until independence is achieved, for example the ability to raise the minimum wage, as supported by the Scottish Trades Union Congress.

7. We will also bring forward a radical package of ideas which demonstrates just how different and better an independent Scotland could be - on currency, welfare, foreign policy, climate change, a post-oil economy and revitalising our democracy.

Scotland can be a beacon, within these islands and beyond, for a socially just and sustainable society. Whilst there are many priorities which will require independence, there is also much that can and must be done now by the Scottish Parliament and the Scottish Government.

Find out more: https://greens.scot/campaign/independence
link_name: Photos from Scottish Green Party's post

Last night Parliament approved the Education Bill.

While it contains many sound principles, Scottish Greens would have preferred to see action to reduce class sizes, protect additional support needs and address teacher workload. 

Isla O'Reilly, Education spokesperson for the Scottish Greens and MSP candidate for Highlands and Islands, said:

"Our concerns about national testing, shared by many parents, teachers and education experts, have been made clear."

Read more here: https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/education-bill-greens-reiterate-concerns-over-testing/

status_message: People directly and indirectly employed by the North Sea oil industry are extremely well placed to drive the transition to renewables. Alison Johnstone explains how Scotland can deliver a safer, more sustainable future by investing in the jobs of tomorrow. #ScotlandCan

We're welcoming the announcement by Scottish Ministers to seek a review of common land legislation, following pressure from Green MSPs who lodged amendments to the Land Reform Bill on the issue.

Holyrood's Rural Affairs Committee did not discuss other amendments put forward by the Green MSPs, aimed at bringing derelict and vacant land into the valuation system to enable the owners to be taxed with those funds used for housebuilding. Those amendments are now due to be heard next Wednesday (3 Feb).

Andy Wightman, Land Reform spokesperson for the Scottish Greens and MSP candidate for Lothian, said:

"The minister's decision to ask the Scottish Law Commission to review the Division of Commonties Act 1695 with a view to its repeal is a welcome move, clearly responding to the amendments put forward to the Bill by Green MSPs."

Read more here:

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/land-reform-greens-in-common-land-win-vacant-land-bid-goes-on/

status_message:
Holyrood's Rural Affairs Committee today rejected amendments we put forward to the Land Reform Bill aimed at stopping tax avoidance.

The amendments would have stopped any land ownership in Scotland by companies and trusts not based in the EU.

The Scottish Government has been resistant to the idea, despite recommendations from the Committee in its stage one report, the Land Reform Review Group and clear support in public consultation.

Andy Wightman, our Land Reform spokesperson and MSP candidate for Lothian, said:

"The committee's refusal to include an EU registration clause in the Bill is extremely disappointing and the continued resistance of Ministers shows how timid the Scottish Government are on this issue."

Read more here: 

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/land-reform-greens-hit-out-at-rejection-of-tax-measures/
link_name: Timeline Photos

Alison Johnstone commenting on the Chief Medical Officer's call to involve patients in care decisions: 

"We absolutely need an NHS that can take care of illness when it occurs, but preventing ill health should be on the top of our priority list. 

"The Scottish Greens believe that to improve our nation's health, we need to tackle low pay that's pushing people into poverty, spend more on walking, cycling and public transport, and invest in warm homes."

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/health-johnstone-urges-focus-on-patient-needs-and-inequality/

status_message:
Scotland can have jobs for the future but we need a bolder Holyrood to achieve it, as today's report from the Economy and Energy Committee shows.

During the committee's inquiry into Oil and Gas, MSPs heard from trades unions representing industry workers that a managed transition toward decommissioning and industries like renewable energy is urgently needed, and that Scotland should be "planning for the North Sea to have a shorter lifespan than previously thought".

However, the committee's report, published today, shows that a proposal from Green MSP Patrick Harvie to support such a transition toward industries with a future was voted down by SNP, Labour and Conservative MSPs.

The same MSPs also voted against Mr Harvie's proposals:
-that the Energy Jobs Taskforce set up by the Scottish Government be given an additional explicit aim of supporting transition;
-that a transition to more sustainable industries was achievable;
-that decommissioning should be prioritised to ensure Scotland doesn't lose out to other countries on contracts for such work.

Read more here:

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/harvie-holyrood-oil-and-gas-report-delusional/
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Scotland is in a housing crisis yet there is 11,000 hectares of vacant and derelict land sitting empty. With radical land reform, we can put it back in use.

Andy Wightman, land reform campaigner and SGP spokesperson on Communities, said:

"By amending the Land Reform Bill, Scotland can tax owners of derelict land, encourage productive use of that land, and bring in much-needed revenue for housebuilding. 

"Scotland can unlock the huge potential in our land but we need Holyrood to be bold."

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/land-reform-green-amendments-to-bill-would-boost-housebuilding/

status_message:
We're challenging the Scottish Government's proposed cut to fuel poverty funding.

The draft 2016/17 Scottish budget proposes £103.3million for fuel poverty measures such as efficient heating systems for people's homes, but this is a drop of £15.7million compared to the current financial year.

At Holyrood today, Patrick Harvie pointed out that such a cut is at odds with the Scottish Government's promise over a year ago that energy efficient housing would become a National Infrastructure Priority.

Read more here:

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/fuel-poverty-harvie-challenges-swinney-over-budget-cut/

status_message:
Time to put #FansFirst! Minister for Sport Jamie Hepburn told our MSP Alison Johnstone today that he will consider fan ownership of football clubs if there is support for it. 

Sign the petition and tell the Scottish Government you want to see a fans' right to buy in Scotland. https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/put-fans-first/

We're highlighting hundreds of communities at risk of flooding but not included on the list of projects funded by the Scottish Government.

The newly-published Flood Risk Management Plan shows that although 252 "Potentially Vulnerable Areas" have been identified, there are only 42 projects funded and only 3 communities getting property level protection (PLP) such as gates for individual houses.

Councillor Mark Ruskell, Climate Change and Environment spokesperson for the Scottish Greens and MSP candidate for Mid-Scotland and Fife, said:

"The terrible flooding experienced across Scotland in recent weeks has caused misery for householders and businesses, and it's simply not credible for the Scottish Government to claim it has fully funded protection measures. Greens have consistently urged greater effort to prepare for increasingly extreme weather events."

Read more here:

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/flooding-greens-highlight-hundreds-of-communities-at-risk/
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Isla O'Reilly, Education, Children and Young People spokesperson for the Scottish Greens and MSP candidate for Highlands and Islands, today reiterated concerns about national testing in primary and secondary schools in light of plans announced by the First Minister.

Local authorities will test reading, writing and numeracy in P1, P4, P7 and S3 with results published nationally each year.

Isla said:

"Class sizes are the largest they've been since 2007, teachers are overworked and additional support needs provision has been cut. Tackling these issues should be the priorities if we are to improve the chances of children from poorer backgrounds."

Read more here:

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/education-greens-reiterate-concerns-about-national-testing/
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
We should all be ambitious for public services, for a more equal society, and for a healthy, balanced and sustainable economy. But that must involve challenging assumptions about what those easy slogans mean in practice.

status_message:
Patrick Harvie MSP, Co-convener of the Scottish Greens, today used the first Holyrood debate of 2016 to speak up for public services and a bolder parliament to bring about a more equal society.

Mr Harvie pointed out that many public services are at risk, and that inequality remains a challenge due to powers retained by Westminster or in the hands of big business.

Patrick Harvie, Finance and Economy spokesperson for the Scottish Greens and MSP for Glasgow, said:

"2016 is an important year for Scotland, with an election that will determine the direction our parliament goes in. After 9 years of the current Scottish Government, fresh thinking and bold ideas are clearly needed, with a strong opposition challenging ministers but also working constructively to take Scotland forward."

Read more here:

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/public-services-harvie-says-bolder-holyrood-is-needed/

We can start by stewarding our pension investments more responsibly to secure the future for ourselves and our children's children.

status_message:
2016 will see our biggest and best election campaign to date. 

An average of the opinion polls during 2015 suggests we'll have 9 MSPs in May, 7 more than we currently have and two more than we had in the 2003-07 session of parliament.

Labour are widely expected to lose at least a dozen MSPs, and the Conservatives and Lib Dems are flat-lining.

In 2016 the Scottish Greens will be the ones to watch.

Read more here:

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/2016-election-harvie-says-greens-are-ones-to-watch/
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
"The successes of our public bodies are team efforts, and rewards should be shared fairly. If we really aspire to a fairer 
Scotland we should be closing the pay gap between the frontline and the boardroom."

Patrick Harvie MSP, Finance and Economy spokesperson for the Scottish Greens, has urged Scottish ministers to review the pay of the most senior public sector officials to prevent six figure
salaries becoming the norm.

Analysis by the Scottish Greens reveals that there are at least 64 employees in the Scottish Government, its non-departmental public bodies and public corporations being paid at least £100,000.

By contrast most public sector staff have seen a real terms pay cut in recent years.

Read more here: 

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/six-figure-salaries-harvie-urges-scottish-government-review/
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Alison Johnstone MSP, Health, Wellbeing and Sport spokesperson for the Scottish Greens, is urging Scottish ministers to rethink their proposed spending plans which are set to slash support for safe walking and cycling routes to schools.AJ on a bike in Midlothian

Analysis by the Scottish Greens shows that the draft 2016/17 budget will cut Cycling, Walking and Safe Routes funding for Local Authorities by £2.1million, while increasing spending on Motorways and Trunk Roads by £125.5million.

Read more here:

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/cycling-funding-flat-johnstone-says-ministers-risking-lives/
link_name: CYCLING FUNDING FLAT: JOHNSTONE SAYS MINISTERS RISKING LIVES

status_message:
Kirsten Robb, Women and Youth Employment spokesperson for the Scottish Greens, is highlighting figures showing the Scottish Government's Modern Apprenticeship programme is continuing to reflect outdated male-female job stereotypes, drawing young women into poorer paid work.

Analysis by the Scottish Greens shows the severe gender imbalance in different sectors has hardly changed since Green MSP Alison Johnstone raised the issue two years ago, with the proportion of young women doing construction apprenticeships falling from just 2 per cent in 2013 to an even lower 1.7 per cent today.

Read more here:

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/apprenticeships-gender-imbalance-greens-highlight-lack-of-progress/
link_name: APPRENTICESHIPS GENDER IMBALANCE: GREENS HIGHLIGHT LACK OF PROGRESS

status_message:
The Scottish Government says it will spend £200 million to cater for rising demand for hip and knee replacements and cataract operations but we've discovered that there's no guarantee that this money will include recruitment of additional staff.

Ministers want to extend the Golden Jubilee Hospital in Clydebank and develop new elective treatment centres at St John's in Livingston, Edinburgh Royal Infirmary, Ninewells Hospital in Dundee, Raigmore Hospital in Inverness and Aberdeen Royal Infirmary.

In response to a parliamentary question from Alison Johnstone, ministers have admitted that they don't know what that £200m cost covers.

Read more here:

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/surgery-centres-johnstone-discovers-no-plans-agreed-despite-fm-pledge/
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Police Scotland's new chief constable starts his job a fortnight today.

If we are to truly get back to community policing, then Police Scotland will have to relinquish its central grip on officers and resources.

Read the latest SGP blog post from our Justice spokesperson, John Finnie MSP, here:

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/blog/if-we-are-to-get-back-to-community-policing-police-scotland-will-have-to-relinquish-its-central-grip-on-officers-and-resources/
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
The latest poll for the Holyrood election in May puts us on 9 per cent on the regional vote, suggesting 9 MSPs. The Lib Dems would only have 2.

Polling during 2015 has suggested that Green MSPs will be elected across each of the 8 parliamentary regions. It has also shown that the 2 Green MSPs – Patrick Harvie and Alison Johnstone – are as trusted to hold the Scottish Government to account as Labour who have 38 MSPs, while Patrick Harvie has the highest approval rating of the Holyrood opposition leaders.

Patrick Harvie MSP, Co-convener of the Scottish Greens, said:

"We're looking forward to 2016 and our biggest and best election campaign to date, and we're determined to convert polling numbers into MSPs to represent all of Scotland's communities. We have our best-ever field of candidates in place and our surging membership means we're visible and active on the ground."

Read more here:

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/more-green-msps-harvie-welcomes-further-strong-polling/
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
845,000 households in Scotland are in fuel poverty. Despite agreeing that energy efficient housing should be a National Infrastructure Priority, ministers have only proposed increasing spending in this area by £14million to £103million.

The draft 2016/17 Scottish budget published today doesn't go far enough on funding for warm homes or low carbon infrastructure, particularly in light of the Paris climate deal.

Patrick Harvie, Finance spokesperson for the Scottish Greens and MSP for Glasgow, said:

"The latest fuel poverty figures are a stark reminder that a transformation in our approach is required, and sadly this budget does not deliver that. It is disappointing that while ministers agree that energy efficient housing should be a National Infrastructure Priority, they are not yet committing to the scale of investment required. This will still take decades to resolve. We need Holyrood to be bolder, and Greens will continue to press the case."

Read more here:

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/draft-budget-harvie-says-fuel-poverty-funding-falls-short/
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
The UK Supreme Court has rejected an appeal brought by US billionaire Donald Trump against plans for the crucial Aberdeen Bay wind project.

The deployment centre of eleven turbines will provide industrial-scale know-how, helping Scotland and in particular the North-east diversify its economy.

Patrick Harvie, Economy spokesperson for the Scottish Greens and MSP for Glasgow, said:

"This crucial project has been delayed for too long by one rich climate change denier. This is the latest rejection for an irrational bully whose brand is increasingly toxic."

Read more here:

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/aberdeen-bay-harvie-welcomes-court-ruling-urges-progress/
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
34 per cent of GPs are over 50 and likely to retire within 10 years, while average practice list sizes have increased by 10 per cent since 2005.

In the same period the number of GP patients aged 65 and over has risen almost 20 per cent from 834,000 to nearly 1 million.

Alison Johnstone, Health spokesperson for the Scottish Greens and MSP for Lothian, said:

"Removing the Quality Outcome Framework points and payment system should help free up GPs to spend more time with patients. The figures out today showing a third of GPs are about to retire while practices have a million patients over 65 emphasise the pressure the system is under."

Read more here:

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/health-johnstone-on-gp-figures-and-contract-change/
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Today's report by the Commission on Local Tax Reform says council tax is "discredited", local government should have a greater choice of taxes, and that Land Value Tax – a longstanding policy of the Scottish Greens – is "promising" and "further work should be done". It recommends transitional relief to enable taxpayers to adjust to any new systems brought in.

Andy Wightman, Scottish Green MSP candidate for Lothian in 2016 and a member of the Commission on Local Tax Reform, said:

"It is vital that the next Parliament puts in place an enduring, stable and flexible fiscal framework for local government that provides fiscal autonomy and enhanced democracy."

Read more here: 

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/council-tax-system-must-end-greens-welcome-report/

status_message:
New NHS figures show nursing, midwifery and consultant vacancies are up.

The proportion of consultant posts lying vacant for more than six months has risen from 0.9 per cent in 2011 to 2.6 per cent this year.

Alison Johnstone MSP, Health and Wellbeing spokesperson for the Scottish Greens, said:

"Although the number of people employed in the NHS overall has slowly risen in recent years, recruitment and retention of key frontline staff has not kept pace. The near-trebling in the rate of consultant vacancies lasting more than six months does not give confidence that Scottish ministers are on top of the situation."

Read more here:

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/nhs-vacancies-johnstone-urges-greater-effort/

According to a new survey of college staff by the Education Institute of Scotland (EIS), the majority of staff members do not believe mergers have delivered on improvements promised. 

Commenting on the findings, Isla O'Reilly, SGP spokesperson on Education, said the figures raise concerns over learning and teaching quality and staff working conditions, and called on the SNP to ensure funds saved in mergers were invested back into colleges.

Isla O'Reilly, Scottish Green MSP candidate for Highlands & Islands, said:

"These figures show that we are dangerously close to slipping back into an unfair two-tier education system, where universities are well-resourced and highly-valued, while college staff are struggling to provide the quality education their students deserve."

Read more here:

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/college-mergers-greens-say-snp-must-not-let-students-down/

Patrick Harvie said:

status_message:
Alison Johnstone, MSP for Lothian and Health and Wellbeing spokesperson for the Scottish Greens, has today highlighted figures showing a continued rise in the proportion of the Scottish population affected by type 2 diabetes.

"The steady increase in diabetes in our population is a huge cause for concern and underlines the need for a proper plan of action and preventative health spending. 

"We know that type 2 diabetes is linked to obesity, poor diet and low levels of physical activity and we know that the condition is more common in deprived areas, so we must do more to help those groups most at risk."

Alison's leading the SGP call for the Government to do more in order to slow what is a very worrying trend. Read more here: https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/category/news/
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
The UK Government is going all out for gas and new nuclear plants.

The challenge for Scottish ministers is to resist this direction of travel.

Scottish Greens have done work to show we can create more and better jobs by moving away from fossil fuels and towards decommissioning, renewables and energy efficiency. 

Patrick Harvie MSP said:

"Energy policy remains reserved to Westminster and we're already seeing Scotland's renewables potential being damaged by wrongheaded decisions by the anti-Green UK Government. A dash for gas will lock us in to further fossil fuel extraction when the scientific consensus is that we need to leave this stuff in the ground. The Tories' obsession with new nuclear ignores the crippling costs and toxic waste legacy."

Read more here:
https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/energy-harvie-urges-scot-gov-to-oppose-uk-dash-for-gas/
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Teaching union the EIS and experts at Stirling University have cast doubt on the Scottish Government's proposed national testing of school pupils.

Isla O'Reilly, Scottish Greens education spokesperson and MSP candidate for the Highlands and Islands, said:

"Children's needs are multiple, and it's simplistic to imagine we can help those from poorer background do better by bringing in national testing. The EIS is right to highlight the lack of resources to deliver what makes a difference, such as smaller class sizes, as this means teachers struggle to get to know their pupils and their circumstances. Standardised testing would take time away from teachers actually teaching."

Read more here:
https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/national-tests-greens-say-teacher-support-more-important/
link_name: Timeline Photos

"The impact of poor quality air and climate change are felt worst by the most vulnerable in our society, and those same people would also benefit most from affordable transport connections. Not everyone has the money to rely on a private car to get to places and to get on with their lives."

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/clean-transport-johnstone-urges-funds-to-tackle-inequality/

status_message:
A new report shows that the Climate Challenge Fund - set up in 2008 thanks to the Green MSPs - has awarded over £66million to deliver 730 community projects aimed at reducing carbon emissions. 

The projects have delivered education, skills, employability, community cohesion, health and wellbeing, and social enterprise developments. 

Patrick Harvie MSP, a member of Holyrood's economy and energy committee, said:

"Green MSPs proposed the Climate Challenge Fund during the previous minority SNP administration and it's great to see it has gone from strength to strength. Giving communities control has been a consistent priority from Green MSPs and it's pleasing to see this review emphasising the wide range of benefits such a scheme can deliver."

Read more: https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/climate-fund-harvie-hails-66m-invested-urges-successor-fund/
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
HMRC staff at offices in Aberdeen, Bathgate, Cumbernauld, Dundee, East Kilbride, Edinburgh, Glasgow, Inverness and Livingston are affected by proposed closures.

John Wilson MSP, employment spokesperson for the Scottish Greens, said:

"I call on HMRC to abandon these plans that if implemented could result in over 2000 jobs lost across Scotland, and force those workers who are not made redundant to travel substantial distances to new sites. We must ensure that we support the workforce and their Trade Unions in the fight to keep these sites open and avoid devastating job losses."

Read more here: https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/hmrc-closures-wilson-urges-support-for-workers-and-trade-unions/

status_message:
New research shows that young people want access to good quality homes and to feel safe in their communities.

The report, by the Beyond4Walls project involving the Poverty Alliance and Children in Scotland, looks at housing, the economy and community issues in Scotland.

Isla O'Reilly, our spokesperson on Education, Children and Young People, and MSP candidate for the Highlands and Islands, said:

"This is welcome research and underlines the benefits to us all if we help our young people get good quality housing, transport and jobs. The needs of young people vary between our cities and rural communities but there are common themes in this report which I'd urge the Scottish Government take on board."

- See more at: https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/young-people-greens-welcome-research-into-housing-needs/#sthash.FDvpgR75.dpuf

A study by industry body Scottish Renewables shows Scotland is on course to generate the equivalent of 87 per cent of its annual demand for electricity from renewables by 2020.

Patrick Harvie MSP said:

"This analysis by Scottish Renewables underlines the wrongheaded approach of the anti-green UK Government and makes clear the need for the Scottish Government to ramp up its efforts on demand reduction. Scottish ministers have agreed with Green calls for warm homes to become a National Infrastructure Priority but they have yet to spell out how that will be achieved."

- See more at: https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/renewables-harvie-on-2020-target-warning/#sthash.TudwVJhc.dpuf

status_message:
The British Medical Association has published its 2016 manifesto, in which it calls for action to fill vacant NHS posts, and preventative measures such as free fruit and vegetables in primary schools.

Alison Johnstone, health spokesperson for the Scottish Greens and MSP for Lothian, said:

"The BMA are right to prioritise recruitment and retention of doctors and prevention of ill-health. These are clear priorities for the Scottish Greens, as we see the benefits of investing in good health now to ease the pressure on the system downstream. We will continue to press this case in the forthcoming Scottish budget."

- See more at: https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/health-johnstone-welcomes-bma-priorities/#sthash.Jzyhvbic.dpuf

status_message:
Scottish Government's latest air pollution strategy does not detail what funding will be allocated to tackle this public health crisis, nor does it pledge any practical measures such as Low Emissions Zones, which have been shown to work elsewhere.

Ministers are spending just £3million this year on air quality measures compared to £700million on building new roads. It is estimated that traffic-related air pollution is responsible for 2,000 premature deaths in Scotland every year.

Alison Johnstone MSP, health spokesperson for the Scottish Greens and MSP for Lothian, said:

"Successive governments and ministers have paid lip service to this public health scandal. Communities affected by dangerous levels of pollution have been waiting too long for practical action and serious investment. Today's publication, focusing on monitoring and awareness campaigns, while glossing over massive roadbuilding budgets, is like Groundhog Day."

- See more at: https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/air-pollution-johnstone-says-latest-strategy-is-groundhog-day/#sthash.ExTc2M02.dpuf
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
The Scottish parliament voted against Trident renewal yesterday, but neither SNP nor Labour took a stand against the pro-nuclear military alliance Nato. Scottish Greens is the only party in Holyrood that opposes Nato membership. 

John Wilson, independent MSP and SGP candidate for Coatbridge and Chryston, said:

"Unless the UK Government, or an independent Scotland, declare their waters a nuclear free zone and reject Nato membership, our opposition to weapons of mass destruction is academic."

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/trident-greens-criticise-piecemeal-opposition-to-nuclear-arms/

According to investigative website The Ferret, the Glasgow City Council internal training course – Protect Against Terrorism – cites "animal rights, environmental, anti-nuclear" as current threats.

GCC staff are also advised to check their neighbour's bins.

Patrick Harvie MSP said:

"It's deeply troubling that anyone would think of putting animal welfare, environmental and anti-nuclear activists in the same category as serious violent terrorists. Peaceful protest is a critical part of a free and democratic culture, and anyone who thinks it should be curtailed in this manner is doing nothing to defend society."

Read more here:  http://greenmsps.org/?p=736

The Scottish Government said there'd be no fuel poverty in the country a year from today. With 940,000 households unable to heat their homes, Scotland have a very long way to go.

"We know that investing in energy efficient homes is one of the best ways to tackle fuel poverty, but if the Government continues at its current rate, it will take decades for all vulnerable people and families in Scotland to have decent warm homes."

The Scottish Government have missed greenhouse emission targets once again. By committing to energy efficient homes, we could tackle fuel poverty and finally meet Scotland's climate aspirations. 

Patrick Harvie MSP and Co-convenor of the Scottish Greens, said: 

"While the SNP push further action until after the May's election, climate change targets remain unmet and tens of thousands of Scots are facing yet another cold winter in homes that are not fit for living."

status_message:
Since 2009 the whole time equivalent number of GPs in Scotland has remained flat at around 3,700.

Today the First Minister announced the extension of a scheme to attract former GPs back to work, and an increase in training places which should mean from 2019 onwards an additional 100 trained GPs available each year.

Alison Johnstone, health spokesperson for the Scottish Greens,  said:

"This focus on recruitment is welcome, if overdue, as we have seen no real increase in capacity at our GP surgeries. GPs tell us that their funding share from the Scottish Government has fallen for the tenth year in a row, while the number of consultations has risen by eleven per cent in the same period."

- See more at: https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/gps-johnstone-says-focus-on-recruitment-overdue/#sthash.ryKTCwZ5.dpuf
link_name: Timeline Photos

"There is clearly work to do to close the inequality gap. In communities where families are struggling to make ends meet we should be increasing our efforts on children's dental health."

- See more at: https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/childrens-teeth-johnstone-says-inequality-must-be-tackled/#sthash.qp1zjnZ8.dpuf

status_message:
"It has to be understood that this is not a conflict of equal forces. Palestine has no standing army, no navy and no airforce. It is not recognised as a state by the world's superpowers and its territory has been continually eroded for decades, with the Gaza strip under an Israeli land, air and sea blockade since 2007. In last summer's Israeli assault on Gaza, over 2,200 Palestinians were killed, of which 65-70% were civilians compared to 72 Israelis of which 66 were soldiers. Every one of these deaths was an unnecessary tragedy but the numbers speak for themselves."

http://news.stv.tv/scotland-decides/analysis/1331171-scottish-greens-why-we-refuse-to-remain-neutral-on-israel-palestine/
link_name: Scottish Greens: Why we refuse to remain neutral on Israel-Palestine

status_message:
We're welcoming the continued campaign from Unite the union to oppose the controversial TTIP trade deal.

Scottish Greens are the only Holyrood party opposed to TTIP. The deal aims to remove barriers to multinational corporations and could enable them to sue governments over profits.

Patrick Harvie, Scottish Green MSP for Glasgow, said:

"Unite are to be praised for their clear position of outright opposition to TTIP. While the exemption of the NHS from the deal is important, the whole deal stinks."

- See more at: https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/ttip-harvie-backs-unite-call-for-cameron-veto/#sthash.Qp7I1a6o.dpuf

status_message:
An Audit Scotland report states that the Scottish Government has not made sufficient progress towards its 2020 vision of more home and community-based healthcare settings, and that there is limited evidence of health boards or the Scottish Government evaluating whether health and care services can adapt to changes in demand.

Alison Johnstone, Scottish Green MSP for Lothian, said:

"This Audit Scotland report is very clear that if we want our NHS to cope with increased demand and rising costs, we need to see a major shift in resources towards preventative and community-based services. Scottish Greens have consistently prioritised preventative spending – investing in good health now so we ease the pressure on the service downstream. We will continue to press this case in the forthcoming Scottish budget."

- See more at: https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/nhs-audit-shows-need-for-preventative-spend-says-johnstone/#sthash.xqrXZIRs.dpuf

Survey of 11,000 people across UK cities including Edinburgh shows 75 per cent want more money invested in cycle infrastructure.

Alison Johnstone, Scottish Green MSP for Lothian and co-convener of Holyrood's cross-party group on cycling, said:

"Public demand for investment in cycling and walking infrastructure in Scotland is clear, with massive events such as Pedal on Parliament. Actions speak louder than words and despite plentiful evidence of the huge benefits for our health, Scottish ministers still spend less than 2 per cent of their £2billion transport budget on cycling and walking."

- See more at: https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/transport-survey-shows-ministers-out-of-step-on-cycling-says-johnstone/#sthash.EbVQoK9v.dpuf

status_message:
It was announced today that steel work plants in Motherwell and Cambuslang would be mothballed, resulting in the potential loss of over 270 jobs.

John Wilson, employment spokesperson for the Scottish Greens and Independent MSP for Central Scotland, said:

"I am concerned for the employees and their families facing this terrible news. Job losses at such a tough time in the economy are a struggle for all those caught up in the unfortunate situation. I will continue to pressure the Scottish Government to support those out of work and to support local trades and business across Scotland; particularly in rural communities where local enterprise is of such importance."

- See more at: https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/steel-wilson-expresses-concern-over-job-losses/#sthash.bFpbmVjH.dpuf

Last week's interview with Patrick:

"Taking energy generation and supply out of the hands of the big international giants and into the hands of local people is his big idea.
"He wants councils and housing associations to generate their own renewable energy and sell a surplus to the grid with profit being invested back in the community.
"It is the Green idea how Scotland can switch from the fossil fuel economy to renewables and reap the economic benefits too."

status_message:
The Federation of Small Businesses wants local economies and small firms at the top of the 2016 election agenda.

Patrick Harvie, Scottish Green MSP for Glasgow and a member of Holyrood's economy committee, said:

"This is a welcome contribution from the FSB. Scottish Greens want to see a small business revolution. Compared to larger corporations they are more likely to be locally owned, have roots in the community and circulate profits and wages locally."

status_message:
"A year on from that day it's clear that the debate isn't over. Polls consistently show that rather than people's hopes for independence being wiped out, they have grown stronger. Maybe that's because some people have had time to reflect, and feel their reluctant No vote was a missed opportunity. Some others voted No because of the promise of deeper devolution, a promise which even Gordon Brown now believes is being broken.

But whatever the reasons, many people on both sides of the independence debate now recognise that 2014 wasn't the end of the story. Scotland will ask itself the question again some day, and even those who sat uneasily together in the Better Together camp last year seem to understand that it's a matter of when, not if."

http://www.thenational.scot/comment/patrick-harvie-we-must-do-things-differently-next-time-around.7709
link_name: Patrick Harvie: We must do things differently next time around

status_message:
We notice some SNP members have formed a group to encourage the Scottish Government to extend its temporary moratorium on fracking.

Patrick Harvie MSP, the Scottish Greens' economy and energy spokesperson, said:

"I welcome the formation of this new group campaigning for the SNP to adopt clear policy against unconventional gas. Communities across central Scotland threatened by fracking and coal gasification are being left in limbo by SNP Ministers trying to face both ways in the run up to an election. SMAUG is right to agitate for an outright ban. Ministers have the power to end this dangerous distraction right now. 
 
"Scottish Greens have been campaigning against unconventional gas extraction for years and led Holyrood's first debate on the issue. We called for a ban and all other parties voted against it. By contrast the SNP only seem able to go so far as permitting a motion at their conference which merely invites ministers to consider extending their temporary moratorium to include coal gasification. This is far short of the permanent ban that our communities want.
 
"With a strong Green voice at Holyrood we can keep pushing the Scottish Government in the right direction."
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Scottish Greens strongly oppose the Tory Government's Trade Union Bill.

Patrick Harvie MSP said:

"There is a critical need for an active trade union movement to represent the interests of working people and to act against exploitation and poor treatment. The UK Government's assault on basic trade union rights is appalling. 

"The STUC is right to demand a strong stance from the Scottish Government and other public sector employers in Scotland - Scottish Greens will support a campaign of non-compliance with this legislation if the UK Parliament passes it. We would hope other parties at Holyrood would agree with that stance. 

"It's deeply regrettable that devolution of trade union laws was blocked in the Smith Commission. We could have done so much more if progress had been made on that."

status_message:
Ross Greer, the Scottish Green Party candidate for West of Scotland, said public money could be better spent: 

"Mrs Windsor has served our nations for an exceptionally long time, an achievement by any measure. However, this day should really be used to celebrate the long-serving public sector workers who keep our country running under increasingly difficult circumstances.

"At the moment, public money is being used to fund a bastion of inherited privilege whilst those in the public sector see their pensions eroded and pay frozen. We'd like to thank Mrs Windsor for her service, but we think the money spent to keep her position going should be used instead to help fund a safe and secure retirement for our public sector workers.

"With an elected head of state and a prosperous economy where workers are treated with dignity and respect, the UK could become a world-leading democracy. That would be something worth celebrating."

http://www.thenational.scot/news/not-one-for-the-jacobites-elizabeths-long-reign-celebrated-in-the-borders.7395
link_name: Not one for the Jacobites: Elizabeth's long reign celebrated in the Borders

status_message:
"The truth is that though countless others have died before this one little boy's photograph caught widespread attention, we do now have a chance to change the tone and purpose of public debate. A human story is being heard instead of statistics. While that cannot bring back any of the thousands who have already died, it might increase the chance that we can end the suffering."

http://www.thenational.scot/comment/patrick-harvie-the-human-story-behind-the-stats-is-finally-heard.7179
link_name: Patrick Harvie: The human story behind the stats is finally heard

status_message:
Independent MSP John Finnie, a Justice Committee member and Scottish Green candidate for 2016, added: "Prior to the advent of the single police service, the common law and statutory powers of stop and search generally worked well across Scotland.

"The understandable public outcry about stop and search, reflected in the comments in this measured UN Human Rights Committee Report, was the result of Police Scotland's decision to use this sensitive tactic on an unprecedented industrial scale."

Finnie said the "disproportionate use" had largely ignored the well understood police powers and instead relied on the "highly dubious tactic" of so-called consensual searches. "Many of those subjected to these consensual searches were minors who were clearly unable to give the necessary informed consent," he said.

http://www.thenational.scot/news/damning-un-human-rights-report-says-non-statutory-stop-and-search-should-end.5575?utm_medium=social&utm_source=Twitter&utm_campaign=Echobox&utm_term=Autofeed#link_time=1437807817
link_name: Damning UN human rights report says non-statutory stop and search should end

A massive congratulations to all our fantastic candidates who did really well in the #GE2015, and a huge thanks to our supporters and all those who voted Green yesterday. There were over a million votes for the combined Green parties. It's not the outcome that many of us were hoping for, but we have a lot to look forwards to.

For all those who didn't have a green candidate in their area, we're really sorry we weren't able to stand a Green candidate in your area. We are doing our best to make sure that we will be fielding a candidate in as many seats as possible for the Holyrood elections next year.  If you would like to be part of the decision-making to ensure that you get a Green candidate in future elections, I would strongly encourage you to join the party and get involved with your local branch! 

But this is not the end. Next year in the #Holyrood #SP2016 election we are polling between 10 and 12 % throughout Scotland and we will be running in every region. 

According to Patrick Harvie MSP , the "Scottish Green campaign teams will be looking forward to mounting our biggest ever campaign, for Holyrood next year. Public polling is consistent and we intend to convert those numbers into a sizeable team of MSPs so the Green Surge transforms Scotland's parliament."

You know the time has come: #VoteGreen2016 !

http://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/scottish-greens-thank-voters-look-to-holyrood-2016/

status_message:
We're really pleased to support the Living Rent Campaign for their Social Media Action day today.

Back in December 2013, Patrick Harvie MSP asked the The Scottish Government to "add further measures to the Housing (Scotland) Bill, such as security of tenure, rent controls and stronger standards in relation to management, housing quality and energy performance." This amendement was voted down and the Housing bill is now in a second consultation phase and we need your help! For more information on Patrick's work since, check this out: http://rentrights.org/

So please help and:
1) Invite 10 friends to like the Living Rent Campaign page: https://www.facebook.com/livingrentcampaign - they are trying to 3000 fans by the end of the day!
2) Follow the Living Rent Campaign on Twitter and retweet one of our infographics: https://twitter.com/Living_Rent/media
3) And most importantly, make sure you have signed the consultation response, and take a moment to share it on social media and encourage your friends to sign it too: www.livingrent.org/action
link_name: Living Rent
Living Rent

status_message:
Patrick's piece for the Left Review:

"Yanis Varoufakis, Greece's new finance minister and a leading figure in Syriza, showed his cultural chops during a Today interview by quoting the poet, Dylan Thomas. He said Greece would not go gentle into the night and would instead rage against the dying of the light. That sort of feisty, principled attitude will be crucial in the coming weeks as those of us on the left advance our arguments for ending austerity and attempt to expose a political system designed to ensure politicians kowtow to big business and wealthy individuals."

"http://www.scottishleftreview.org/feature/adding-red-to-the-green/

Patrick has just lodged a motion calling for STV to host a fair and balanced debate. Ask you MSPs to support it today.

Motion S4M-12751: Patrick Harvie, Glasgow, Scottish Green Party, Date Lodged: 19/03/2015
STV Debate 

That the Parliament notes the proposal by STV to host a Scottish debate in advance of the UK General Election; believes that all five parties represented in the Scottish Parliament should be invited to participate in the debate; welcomes the agreement of Nicola Sturgeon, Jim Murphy, Ruth Davidson and Willie Rennie that this should happen, and urges STV to meet representatives of the five parties to agree how this debate can be structured fairly.

status_message:
WOMEN'S NETWORK LOTHIAN HOLYROOD HUSTINGS: TUES 10 MARCH 7.15PM

A reminder that hustings will take place for candidates who have put themselves forward for the Lothian regional list for the 2016 Holyrood elections on Tuesday 10 March at the Friends Meeting House, Victoria Terrace, Edinburgh between 7.15 and 9pm.

The hustings will provide you with an opportunity to hear from and quiz candidates who have put themselves forward for selection, ahead of placing your vote.

Given that the Scottish Green Party will return at least one MSP and up to two more MSPs for the Lothian Region in 2016, it is  important that you hear from and have a say over the people that will potentially go on to represent the party in the Scottish Parliament.

The hustings are open to all Women's Network members in the Lothian Region and I would strongly encourage members to come along - with some questions!

It's International Women's Day today. At our conference yesterday, our Co-Convener Maggie Chapman said "It's appalling that in 2015, despite decades-old legislation, equal pay and gender equality across all levels of work remain unfinished business"
link_name: SCOTTISH GREENS CONFERENCE: GENDER EQUALITY PRIORITY

status_message:
SCOTTISH GREENS CONFIRM CANDIDATES FOR BIGGEST MP PUSH

The Scottish Greens announce today that we will stand candidates in over half of Scotland's 59 Westminster constituencies - more than ever before - with 40 per cent of the candidates women.

A full list of candidates can be found here:
http://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/campaigns/westminster2015/

This follows a surge in membership to over 8,500 and a steady rise in the polls with a recent TNS Scottish survey putting the Greens on 6 per cent, two points ahead of the Libdems. The same poll revealed that almost of a quarter of 18 to 34 year olds intend to vote for the Scottish Greens.

Edinburgh East is the top target constituency with former university rector Peter McColl the party's candidate. Edinburgh has a strong Green activist base, and has had MSPs since 1999 and councillors since 2007.

Patrick Harvie MSP, Co-convener of the Scottish Greens, said:
"Other parties are tying themselves in knots with messages about the sort of tactical voting that represents the politics of old. With our biggest slate of candidates, Scots will have an unrivalled opportunity to vote for the bold and positive politics that only Greens represent.

"Our candidates are already out and about engaging with voters on our ideas for protecting public services, reforming democracy and tackling inequality. With new members joining all the time we are determined to maintain the momentum."

Peter McColl, Scottish Green candidate for Edinburgh East, said:
"Greens are clearly in the running as we head into an election in which everything is up for grabs. We know from speaking to our local communities that voters are looking for candidates they can believe in.

"Our policies on raising the minimum wage to £10 a hour by 2020, renationalising the railways and ending austerity have huge appeal, and are vital to rebalancing our economy and our society."
link_name: Timeline Photos

Patrick Harvie MSP warned that the plans were a challenge to civil liberties.

"Glaswegians are already under far more surveillance than most of us are aware of, and this is a serious challenge to our privacy and civil liberties," he said.

"It's a vital principle that we are all innocent until proved guilty, but in the age of mass surveillance we're all treated as suspects every day of our lives.

I call on Glasgow City Council to disclose the nature of all surveillance systems they use now or are planning to use, and to consult the public on how they will operate and what democratic controls are in place to limit the power of those currently watching our every step."

status_message:
The Aberdeen University Greens are pleased to announce that Maggie Chapman (co-convenor of the Scottish Greens and our University Rector) and Debra Storr (former Aberdeenshire councillor and local Aberdeen activist) will be holding a talk and fielding questions in our inaugural event. 

Both speakers will be discussing the Scottish Green Party at a national and local level, explaining exactly who we are, and what we aim to achieve. The talks will be followed by a Q&A if you have any questions that are keeping you up at night, this will be the perfect opportunity to get them answered!

Food will be available at the Shared Planet Café in Butchart from 5pm onwards, and we hope to get the talks started around 5:20. Afterwards we will be heading over to the Bobbin for a more relaxed discussion where you can get to know the committee and hear about our plans for the coming semester, so please feel free to join us there!

https://www.facebook.com/events/383601081819994/?ref=4
link_name: The Greens: What do we stand for?

status_message:
Tomorrow Alison Johnstone will be speaking at the foot of The Mound as part of Global Divestment Day, calling on institutions to do what's necessary to avert the climate crisis by divesting from fossil fuels.
Recently, she was able to secure a pledge from John Swinney that Scotland's large public pension investments will be made more transparent, so that local government employees can see where investments are going. You can read more about this here: http://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/…/johnstone-secures-trans…/
We have already seen moves towards divestment driven by student campaigns on campus - not least in Glasgow, where Glasgow University became the first in Europe to divest from fossil fuels. http://www.theguardian.com/…/glasgow-becomes-first-universi…
It is important that we can communicate to people just what power individuals and groups can have to influence government and corporate attitudes on this issue.
You can find more info on Global Divestment Day here: http://gofossilfree.org/uk/global-divestment-day/
link_name: Global Divestment Day

status_message:
To our Greek friends,

The International Committee of the Scottish Green Party welcome the Syriza victory in Greece and congratulate our fellow Greens and members of the wider European Green family. Too often in recent history have the peoples of Europe been offered only a choice between resignation or despair. The left coalition, Syriza, including yourselves, the Greek Ecologist Greens, has proven that hope can also find space on the ballot. We believe that you are best placed to end this period of austerity and reverse the effects of such destructive policies. This election could be the catalyst for a new dynamic in European politics and parties, leading to a more progressive, greener, people's Europe, giving people hope for the future and helping to strengthen democracy in Greece.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
It's only exit polls so far but even with a healthy margin of error the results in Greece are quite clear. It's a win for SYRIZA! Here is our statement to our friends in SYRIZA, including the Greek Greens:

The International Committee of the Scottish Green Party welcome the Syriza victory in Greece and congratulate our fellow Greens and members of the wider European Green family. Too often in recent history have the peoples of Europe been offered only a choice between resignation or despair. The left coalition, Syriza, including yourselves, the Greek Ecologist Greens, has proven that hope can also find space on the ballot. We believe that you are best placed to end this period of austerity and reverse the effects of such destructive policies. This election could be the catalyst for a new dynamic in European politics and parties, leading to a more progressive, greener, people's Europe, giving people hope for the future and helping to strengthen democracy in Greece.

status_message:
If only we could contest all elections via twitter.

"In our Twitter sampling, 79% of the comments made about Patrick Harvie were positive, in contrast to, for example, 58% of comments about Nicola Sturgeon, 21% about Douglas Alexander or 12% about Ruth Davidson. The only other person to come close to Harvie was Elaine C Smith, with 68% of the comments about her being positive.

Comments about Harvie focused on his ability as a debater, describing him as "eloquent", "unflappable" and "a fresh breath of air". Tweeters also praised his contribution to the campaign as a whole. Indeed, even before he spoke, his contribution was being anticipated by some tweeters: 'Yay, it's Patrick next!' 

http://theconversation.com/general-election-leaders-debate-should-be-more-diverse-indyref-research-suggests-36322

status_message:
SCOTTISH GREENS WELCOME GREEK GREEN-LEFT ALLIANCE

Scottish Greens Co-Convener Maggie Chapman today welcomed the decision by the Greek Ecologist Greens to join SYRIZA, the Coalition of the Radical Left, ahead of the Greek general election on 25 January. SYRIZA stand a good chance of winning the election, which is widely seen as a referendum on the austerity imposed by the 'Troika' of the European Central Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the European Commission.

Cllr Chapman said:

"The Scottish Greens welcome the decision of our Greek comrades to join SYRIZA, the Coalition of the Radical Left, ahead of this month's election. SYRIZA are the party best placed to end the worst cuts, and put Greece back on the road to democracy.

"At our conference last year, the Scottish Greens made clear that we are totally opposed to the austerity being imposed on Greece and other European countries. We stand in solidarity with the people of Greece in their fight for decent lives and against austerity. "

link_name: Edinburgh Green Party

status_message:
Our reaction to today's Labour leadership election. 

Congratulations to Jim & Kezia but it's time for progressive, anti-austerity, anti-Trident Labour members to join a party which truly represents their values. With one in ten Greens an ex-Labour member, we would welcome those who find today's decision to be a red line crossed.

https://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/news/greens-comment-on-murphy-election/

status_message:
Glasgow and West of Scotland Festive Get Together!

Wednesday 17th December, Broadcast, Sauchiehall Street

Join us for an evening of live music treats, finishing with disco beats.
We've a fantastic range of creative members and supporters now, all keen to chip in and make this a night to remember (or not, depending on the quanities of Irn-Bru we drink).

Expect a mix of music and creative delights to suit all ears. Line up will be announced soon.

Venue has both upstairs and downstairs spaces. Downstairs is standing only and is where most of the live music will be. Upstairs is wheelchair accesible, with both seating and standing room, a bar and banter. 

Due to licencing laws, the event is only open to over 18s.

All funds raised will go to Glasgow and West of Scotland Greens coffers to support our work going forward.

Tickets are £10, or £5 for concessions, and available here:

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/glasgow-greens-festive-social-tickets-14472275967

£10 an hour minimum wage, ending poverty pay

Renationalising the railways, making public transport about public need and not private profit

Scrapping Trident, because £100bn on nuclear weapons when people are going hungry is reprehensible.

Fair votes, when two in three MP don't get the MP they vote for it suggests a better, proportional system is needed.

status_message:
FRACKING: HARVIE URGES MINISTERS TO ADOPT TOUGHER LINE

Patrick Harvie, Green MSP for Glasgow, today (30 Sep) used Topical Questions at Holyrood to urge Scottish ministers to adopt a tougher line on fracking.

A vast swathe of Scotland, from Argyll to Aberdeenshire and from Ayrshire to East Lothian, has been earmarked by the UK Government as ripe for the controversial gas drilling technique.

Last week the UK Government agreed to pass laws to let fracking companies drill below people's homes without consent, despite a consultation showing that 99% of responses oppose such a move.

Patrick Harvie MSP said:

"Drilling for gas will add massively to the existing stocks of fossil fuels - stocks we can't afford to burn. The recent climate summit in New York has reminded us of the profound threat we face if we keep pumping greenhouse gases into the atmosphere.

"Communities across Scotland are rightly alarmed at the determination of the Tory-LibDem coalition to allow fracking. Today I urged Scottish Ministers to take a tougher line, given their recent description of fracking as an opportunity and their failure to ban it with the planning powers they already have.

"I welcome John Swinney's commitment not to replicate the UK Government's approach to drilling without consent, if the power to take action is devolved to Holyrood. However he has still not ruled out allowing fracking itself to go ahead in Scotland, and if we're going to protect communities and the environment we'll need both the power to legislate, and the political will to do so."

link_name: Highlands and Islands Green Party

status_message:
SCOTTISH GREENS THANK OVER 3,000 NEW MEMBERS

The Scottish Greens are thanking over 3,000 new members who have joined the party since the close of polls on Thursday evening.

This means total membership has just passed the 5,000 mark. The surge is also being seen on social media. The Scottish Greens' twitter account - @scotgp - now has over 18,200 followers compared to Scottish Labour's 13,000.

Recent opinion polls have put support for the Greens on 10 per cent on the Holyrood regional vote, suggesting 11 MSPs, which would make the Scottish Greens the parliament's third largest party, one MSP ahead of the Conservatives.

In May's European election the Scottish Greens secured 108,000 votes, coming ahead of the Lib Dems in 21 of Scotland's 32 local authority areas.

Comments on social media from those joining the party include:

"Excited to be part of such a progressive movement."
"Patrick Harvie is absolutely fantastic."
"I've joined @scotgp to help bring about positive, sustainable change."
"First time I've been a member of a political party."
"Spent most of the #indyref campaign wishing green matters would get more attention."
"Found @patrickharvie's arguments compelling throughout #indyref campaign."
"Let's get working for a fairer Scotland."

Commenting, Scottish Greens co-convenor Patrick Harvie MSP said:

"I want to thank the vast number of people who have been in touch over recent days to offer support, share their thoughts about the Green Yes campaign, and to join the party in their thousands – including those who voted Yes and No. We'll be going into the next election as a much bigger party than we could have imagined, and the potential clearly still exists for a dramatic realignment of Scotland's political landscape.

"There are many ideas being debated about what that realignment will result in, but the Greens have never been the kind of party where a handful of people in leadership roles impose their own decisions on the rest. Our local branches are currently debating the next steps, our national council will meet on Saturday, and our members new and old will meet at our biggest conference even on October 11th to start making our decisions together.

"One thing is very clear to me. As well as the huge numbers of Yes voters who sought the kind of radical change that Westminster is unlikely to deliver, there are also many who voted No but who share our commitment to a sustainable economy, a fair and equal society, and a renewed democratic culture.

"Making that happen will mean finding ways to work together. We have always been a party that seek to work with others where common ground exists, while still offering a robust challenge where we must on the core principles of the Green agenda. I'm very excited to know that we'll be doing so as a far bigger party in future."

The party is now looking ahead to its conference on the 11th & 12th October in Edinburgh, set to be its largest ever.

Key speakers include Green MSPs Patrick Harvie and Alison Johnstone, former First Minister Henry McLeish, trade unions and NGOs.

External Organisations: Book your fringe meeting at the Scottish Greens' biggest-ever annual conference: 11-12 October  
 
With the referendum campaign now behind us, the Scottish Greens are looking forward to our annual conference in Edinburgh on 11-12 October. We've always welcomed dozens of Scotland's best campaigning, representative and trade organisations to book a fringe meeting or have a presence at the event.
 
Following a huge increase in membership of and interest in the Greens, this conference will be 2-3 times larger than any previous events.  Key speakers include Green MSPs, Patrick Harvie and Alison Johnstone, former First Minister Henry McLeish as well as many others from trade unions, local authorities, NGOs and churches.
 
So do please book your place and return as soon as possible: http://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/conference-2014/external-organisations/
 
With best wishes
 
Maire McCormack
Conference Organising Team
07516 765902
link_name: Conference 2014 - for External Organisations

status_message:
HARVIE TO OUTLINE BREADTH OF YES TO WORLD MEDIA

Patrick Harvie, Co-convener of the Scottish Greens, will today join other leading figures in the Yes campaign to outline the breadth of the pro-independence movement to a large audience of international media.

Mr Harvie, whose party has been running its own distinct Green Yes campaign, will speak in Edinburgh alongside the First Minister, Deputy First Minister, Canon Kenyon Wright who chaired the Scottish Constitutional Convention in the 1990s, and Anum Qaisar of Muslim Friends of Labour.

Patrick Harvie MSP said:

"One of the most exciting aspects of this campaign is how broad the Yes movement has become, and Scottish Greens have played a significant part, taking our message far and wide. The level of engagement from the public is amazing and I believe the prospect of building a better democracy has been a key motivating factor.

"Yes has been a wonderful and creative movement, but this debate has already gone way beyond the Yes and No campaigns, and is now being driven by ordinary people having conversations about the kind of country they want to see. The days of aloof leaders telling us how it's going to be are over."
The French Green Party, EELV, says YES to an independent Scotland!
