status_message:
New Scottish Greens member Ross Craig attended a "meet and greet" day with the Green MSPs at the Scottish Parliament. Here, he shares his thoughts on the day with us.

As a recent new member of the Scottish Greens I was delighted to be invited to a meet and greet with Alison Johnstone and Patrick Harvie at the Scottish Parliament. Arriving early I was welcomed by Scottish Greens staff who warmly welcomed me and other new Greens. We were in time to sit in the gallery and observe a hotly debated motion on the future of Trident in Scotland. The motion was put forward by Patrick and was successfully argued! The chamber was full and it was a pleasure to witness democracy in action especially on such an important issue. Patrick was by far and away the best orator on the subject and he handled the dissenters very well. I was delighted when the parliament carried his motion.

After the debating action we were guided by the staff to a meeting room where we held exclusive audience with Patrick and Alison. Both were very genuine and welcoming. It was only at this point did I see the huge turnout from new Green members. The meeting room was full and there was standing room only! New Greens from all sections of society numbering over 50. It was fantastic to hear all the points from like minded people.

After 30 minutes or so we left the parliament and went to a nearby pub. I got the chance to speak to lots of the new members and to Patrick and Alison too. The enthusiasm for our Green Party is infectious and I left feeling very positive about the upcoming referendum and the annual conference.

It's hard to believe that such a landmark vote is happening in such a short time. A vote where we can really shape our future and take responsibility for ourselves. Like a young person leaving the family home we won't be abandoned by our commonwealth cousins and nor are we to blame for breaking away from years of Union. It's time to go it alone and the Greens are ready to participate in a modern and revitalised Scotland. Ready to abandon the old values and fears behind nuclear capability. Ready to allow local people to make decisions that affect local communities. Ready to look after our environment and society with greater conscience than ever before.

Amongst the absentees from the debating chamber was First Minister Salmond. Remember that September's vote isn't about him or the SNP it's about Scotland looking out for itself. Don't mistake the referendum for a personality contest but as an opportunity that future generations will be grateful for.
link_name: Meeting Our MSPs As A New Member

Almost half a million Green Yes booklets are starting to be distributed to households across the country. They emphasise that independence offers future generations a chance to truly shape the direction of Scotland. The booklet highlights key opportunities including: 

- Sharing Scotland's undoubted wealth more equally 
- Creating a fairer tax system 
- Creating better jobs with good wages 
- Prioritising investment in renewable energy 
- Rebuilding a welfare system that allows everyone to meet their needs 
- Reforming the banks to serve the public good 
- Tackling the poverty that leads to health inequalities 
- Removing Trident, inspiring disarmament across Europe 
- Starting a debate about the Head of State 

If you want a sneak peek at the leaflet, you can find it here:
https://gallery.mailchimp.com/efa534ce2e2f79f5dc6c7a5fc/files/Summer_leaflet_v3.pdf

status_message:
We published our latest Green Yes Briefing Note yesterday, with our plans to replace most benefits and the state pension and replace it with a Citizen's Income, which would see 70% of households better off.

Under the model detailed in the paper: 

- Weekly payments are proposed of £50 to children, £100 to adults and £150 to pensioners.
- 70 per cent of households would be better off than presently. 
- Those in the lowest income bracket would benefit the most. 
- Measures of inequality would be brought in line with some of the most equal countries in the world. 
- Income earned in addition to the citizen's income would continue to be taxed progressively.

You can read the briefing paper here: http://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/downloads/2014/08/Citizens-Income-Briefing-Note.pdf

And for more of our briefing notes, including ones on banking, local democracy, and digital rights, you can find our publications page here:
http://www.scottishgreens.org.uk/publications/
So close to our £5000 target this early. be the lovely person who gets us there tonight!
link_name: Green Yes - This Is It

Power of Scotland

Scotland is the principal source of Britain's renewable energy as well as its oil and gas. What would independence mean for the UK energy market? Would England struggle to source clean energy? Could Scotland continue to subsidise its wind turbines and tidal energy schemes? What would a split mean for energy prices in Scotland and in the rest of the UK?

Tom Heap reports from Edinburgh on an energetic debate that's certain to heat up as the Scottish independence referendum approaches.

This afternoon, Radio 4, 3.30pm
link_name: BBC Radio 4 - Costing the Earth, Power of Scotland

status_message:
MARGO: GREEN MSPs PAY TRIBUTE

Scottish Green MSPs are paying tribute following news of the death of Independent MSP Margo MacDonald.

Patrick Harvie, Green MSP for Glasgow, said:

"I have felt deeply privileged to work with Margo MacDonald on many issues in my time as an MSP, particularly in recent years through forming the Green/Independent Group and working together on the Assisted Suicide Bill. I've always enjoyed the wit and sparkle she brought to debates in the Chamber, but she could also offer a formidable challenge when it was needed, and showed long term dedication to the causes she chose to work for.

"Margo won't now see the culmination of two debates she was deeply involved in; the referendum on Scotland's independence, and the Assisted Suicide Bill which she introduced last year. But as both these debates continue, I am certain that campaigners on all sides will recognise Margo MacDonald's contribution to Scottish public life, her vibrancy and her passion. I know I'll miss her every time I walk into the Chamber."

Alison Johnstone, Green MSP for Lothian, said:

"Margo MacDonald was a one-off. Compassionate and brave, she was a role model for new and experienced politicians alike.

"Her no-nonsense approach was massively popular with the people in Lothian she represented so well. Regardless of party affiliations Margo's star quality was indisputable. She will be much missed."

status_message:
Father of Green co-convenor dies

It is with great sadness that we have to inform you that Neil Chapman, the father of Scottish Greens co-convenor and European Parliament candidate Maggie Chapman, passed away last Thursday, 20 March. The funeral will be held tomorrow in Harare, Zimbabwe.

Neil Chapman was a distinguished classical musician and an expert on the Shona and Ndebele music of Zimbabwe. Born in South Africa in 1933, he moved to Harare in 1978 and spent two decades as head of the Zimbabwe College of Music. He led the City of Harare Orchestra, and was awarded the dignity of a Chevalier of the Legion d'Honneur for services to music. 

Neil passed away at 3.15pm local time on Thursday 20 March at St Anne's Hospital, Harare, after an extensive surgery for cancer. Maggie and his wife Emma were by his side.

Neil is survived by his wife Emma, his daughters Catherine and Maggie, his two sisters and two granddaughters.

status_message:
TONY BENN: SCOTTISH GREEN CO-CONVENOR COMMENT

Maggie Chapman, co-convenor of the Scottish Greens and the party's candidate for the European election, has spoken of her sadness at the death of socialist Tony Benn.

Maggie Chapman said:

"Tony Benn was a truly great man, and a hero for me as he was for so many others.

"He taught us how to be socialists; he was a ferocious fighter when necessary, but also full of humour, openness, patience, and love. He trusted working people above elites, always - the mark of a true democrat.

"Instead of being tamed by his background or ministerial experience, he learned how the British state is run for vested interests. He struck a blow against the hereditary principle and demanded radical democratisation.

"He spoke up against the UK's involvement in illegal overseas wars and was a great supporter of workers controlling their own workplaces through cooperatives.

"Tony Benn's greatest legacy is the millions he inspired, who will continue his life's struggle against elites, against war and for a more equal world."

The European Parliament is inquiring into mass surveillance by governments, following Edward Snowden's revelations about the NSA. Unbelievably, many right-wing MEPs didn't even want to let him talk to the inquiry.

Thanks to Green MEPs like Jan Philipp Albrecht, though, Snowden's testimony will now be accepted before the final report is voted on.

Privacy rights will take a constant fight in the digital age. Let's keep Greens in the Parliament to stand up for citizens, not corporations or government agencies. Change Europe, Vote Green!
link_name: NSA scandal Snowden testimony to be accepted by EP inquiry, appropriate platform must be guaranteed

THIS FRIDAY: 2014 will be a big year for Scotland, and whatever happens in politics Scotland is seeing a cultural renaissance like never before. As the prospect of a new Scotland looms, what does it mean for Scottish culture?

In a conceptual event organised jointly by Edinburgh Green Party,  Greenlight and the Post collective, we'll ask musicians, artists, poets and politicians what it all means for them as we take over Summerhall's grand Main Hall for the evening.

There'll be performances, questions and the famous Royal Dick Bar.
link_name: New Scotland, New Culture? | Summerhall

As The Spectator acknowledges, it's a fight between UKIP and the Scottish Greens for the country's 6th MEP slot. They've got a Scottish leader who says that Glasgow is run by "Gays, Catholics [and] Communists", and that the Scottish Defence League should be free to spread their hatred. He says of "islamist influence in the SNP and Labour" that at a Glasgow election count "I thought we were contesting a seat in Pakistan.lol"

They've also got multi-millionaire backers. We've got you guys. Help us defeat them in May and keep UKIP's hate and prejudice out of Scotland. Donate via our Indiegogo campaign:
link_name: Elect Maggie Chapman & Stop UKIP In Scotland

status_message:
A message from Zara Kitson, our Dunfermline candidate:

"I'd like to thank the many activists and supporters who gave me such strong backing during the campaign. As a grassroots party Scottish Greens are not backed by wealthy individuals or corporate interests but we didn't shrink from the fight.

"By listening to the people of Dunfermline and the West Fife villages I was able to campaign on issues of importance to local people, from the bedroom tax and school closures to energy bills and fan ownership of the Pars. I wish Cara Hilton well as the new MSP and look forward to seeing Green support in the region continue to grow."

Patrick Harvie MSP, Co-convener of the Scottish Greens, said:

"Zara is definitely one to watch. Her incredibly positive and constructive campaign switched people on to the full range of Green policies. We look forward to building on the good work of Zara and her team in the region in the months and years ahead."

status_message:
As many of you will already be aware, Zara Kitson is standing as the Scottish Green Party candidate in the Dunfermline by-election to the Scottish Parliament on October 24th. We're keen to get started with the campaign straight away and so our first action day will be this coming  Saturday 28th September. We will be meeting at  10.30am at Dunfermline Queen Margaret train station, just look for the folk with the Green rosettes!
 
It would be fantastic if you could make it along to help Zara spread our message, even if you can only help out for a short time. We'll be speaking to voters to find out what their concerns are as well as collecting signatures for our petition against evictions caused by the bedroom tax. This is a great opportunity to meet other Greens and get some campaigning experience with knowledgeable members on hand. Patrick Harvie MSP will be joining us in the afternoon.
 
We will also be out every Saturday and Sunday between now and polling day. The only exception to this is the weekend of the 5/6th October which is party conference. If you are not attending conference but would be interested in campaigning in Dunfermline please let me know at: ross.greer@dunbartonshiregreens.org.uk as soon as possible and we can look at organising something. Further details for future campaign days will come next week. If you are available to campaign at any point  Monday-Friday could you again please let me know as teams will be out as and when volunteers are available.

-Ross Greer
Patrick Harvie will be on Newsnight Scotland in just over an hour, talking about identity and diversity in modern Scotland

status_message:
Edinburgh Greens are seeking alternatives to what they dub a "grow-grow-grow" plan for Edinburgh
 
At a meeting open to the public this Thursday evening (26 September) the Greens will examine the draft Local Development Plan for the city, which is due to go live in 2015.
 
The Plan sets out the big picture for land use in the city in light of a projected growth of 68,000 households through to 2031.  To date there has been controversy about the potential loss of greenbelt land to the south and west of the city.  The Plan also nestles within the so-called "SESPlan" which sets the context for the wider city region and has increased the land allocation for housing to over 100,000.  SESPlan is due to be discussed between all councils in the south east of Scotland next Monday (30 September).
 
Green councillor Nigel Bagshaw said:
 
"The Local Development Plan is central to how Edinburgh will be shaped over the next 20 years.  There's a fundamental question to be addressed as to how big we want Edinburgh to be and what the consequences are for greenbelt, agriculture, transport links and the future design of neighbourhoods.
 
"Beyond those questions, the city needs to do more to make better use of existing sites and existing empty properties; and to make sure that new homes are affordable and in sufficient density to support local services like shops, healthcare and public transport.  
 
"Future generations won't thank us for making the wrong choices now."
 
The meeting is at 7.30pm on Thursday 26 September at the Quaker Meeting House, 7 Victoria Terrace.   
ENDS

status_message: It's a year until the independence referendum. Patrick Harvie will be on The Debate tonight on BBC1 from 9pm, with a vision of what a greener, more sustainable independent Scotland could look like.

The British Government and the Opposition both seem to have no idea how to get out of this economic depression. One suggests austerity, hitting the poorest hardest and throwing millions into unemployment as the economy nosedives. The other suggests almost the same policies, but cutting a little slower.

Are there better ideas for tackling this economic slump? Would independence give Scotland special opportunities to develop a fairer economy?

Join Edinburgh Greens tonight from 7pm in Summerhall Dissecting Room to discuss these ideas. More details here
link_name: What Sort Of Economy For Our Future?

The Dundee Green Party will be holding its AGM on Monday 9th September at Botanic Gardens.

The AGM will commence at 6.30 with a look at the UK's first energy autonomous building at the Botanic Gardens which is a 50m2 building due to be completed in September to Passivhaus Standards with super-insulated walls and 25m2 of solar photovoltaic panels amongst other features. 

This will be followed, at 7pm by a talk about this building by Dr Neil Burford, School of Architecture, University of Dundee.

The AGM will commence at 7.30 - all welcome!

status_message:
Alison writes…

Patrick and I have received a huge volume of correspondence from our constituents, calling on us to support the IF campaign.

The IF campaign is a vast coalition of charities and organisations demanding an end to global hunger. You can read more about the campaign on their website.

There is no need for hunger – it is a symptom of gross inequality, not of a lack of resources. We can feed the world's population, but it will require much more assertive action than governments have been prepared to take to date.

A lot of the problem goes beyond the scope of the Scottish Parliament, but that shouldn't stop Scotland making the most of the powers it does have at its disposal.

In response to the calls of my constituents, I wrote to the First Minister, putting the demands of the campaign's supporters directly to the Scottish Government.

You can read the Minister for External Affairs and International Development's response on the link below.

Please be assured that both Patrick and I will continue to challenge the Scottish Government to do more to tackle the issues highlighted by the IF campaign.
link_name: http://www.greenmsps.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/130704-Humza-Yousaf-IF-Campaign.pdf

status_message:
Panorama, tonight, 2030 on BBC One:

When Donald Trump offered to bring six thousand jobs and a billion pounds in investment to Scotland with two world class golf courses, a five star hotel and hundreds of homes, it seemed to many an opportunity not to be missed even though it would mean sacrificing an environmentally protected part of the Scottish coastline. Five years on from Trump's controversial planning victory one golf course has been built, the hotel and property build is on hold while the accounts show investment of around £25 million and, according to the Trump Organisation, 200 jobs have been created rather than the thousands promised. With the land estimated now to be worth around ten times what it was thanks to the outline planning consents, Panorama reporter John Sweeney asks if the Scottish Government knew enough about the self-proclaimed billionaire before saying yes and challenges Donald Trump to reveal what's behind the Trump brand.
link_name: BBC One - Panorama, The Trouble with Trump

status_message:
Aberdeen Green Party has selected local campaigner Rhonda Reekie as its candidate to contest the Aberdeen Donside Scottish Parliament by-election.

Rhonda Reekie lives at the heart of the Aberdeen Donside constituency, in Bucksburn. An active member of the local community, Rhonda is on Bucksburn and Newhills Community Council and the Beacon Community Centre management team. Rhonda is involved in several local environmental initiatives, including the creation of a community herb garden, looking after the Old Meldrum Road flower beds and a woodland project at Sclattie Woods in co-operation with Bucksburn Academy.

Born in Lanarkshire, Rhonda, 47, moved to Aberdeen aged 11. She attended Bridge of Don Academy and went on to study molecular and cell biology at Aberdeen University. Married to Andrew, she and her husband have lived in Bucksburn for the past 13 years. Rhonda lists her hobbies as gardening, community work, reading and cookery. She works as a freight forwarding manager for a company in Aberdeen.

Rhonda is an active political campaigner; for example, she was heavily involved in the successful campaign to save Union Terrace Gardens. Rhonda has been a member of the Scottish Green Party for ten years and has previously stood as a Green candidate in council, Holyrood and Westminster elections. She is also a member of Amnesty, the League Against Cruel Sports and Friends of the Earth. Rhonda is pro-independence.

Rhonda Reekie said, "The Green Party will be putting forward a positive message for Aberdeen Donside. We want to protect and improve the local environment. We see energy conservation and renewable energy projects, for example the wind turbine test centre in Aberdeen bay, as a route to new and sustainable jobs for the North-east. We want better public transport across the City, including improvements to the train service in and out of Aberdeen and additional stations. We will campaign for a fairer society - for example, by opposing the 'Bedroom Tax'.

Promoted by John McCallum on behalf of Rhonda Reekie, both contactable at 4c 37 Skene Square, Aberdeen AB25 2UP
We should give people something they can get behind. Oh, and Patrick has the highest approval rating of any Scottish party leader!

status_message:
Following discussions with South Lanarkshire Council, our Green Screen showing of the Vanishing of the Bees will go ahead as planned at Biggar Corn Exchange on Fri 18th Jan, but we will be donating any profits to WWF. Tickets from http://www.biggarcornexchange.org.uk/tickets.asp

In the longer term we will be working with the Trust which runs the Corn Exchange to find a way to be able to run fund-raisers for the party. SLC's problem seems to be in their interpretation of the trust's Articles of Association, which in their view (but not the Trust's) does not allow political funders to take place in the building. 

It's not as if the Trust itself is raising money for a political party - just the opposite in fact - we are giving it money for use of the building! However it may take some time to get SLC to see sense and we have needed to make a decision now to enable the screening of this important film to go ahead.
link_name: Biggar Corn Exchange | Tickets

status_message:

Some pro-Palestinian protestors have been arrested this afternoon after taking to the roof of the Scottish Parliament. Scottish Green MSPs have called on the Scottish Government to join the global movement for boycotts, divestment and sanctions in support of Palestinians.

Incidentally, our Edinburgh branch are holding a meeting tonight at which the situation in Gaza will be discussed. Guest speakers are from the Scottish Palestinian Solidarity Committee, The Scottish Palestinian Forum and the San Gahn'ny Choir.

The meeting is from 7.30-9.30 in the Quaker Meeting House, Victoria Terrace (above Victoria Street), with drinks afterwards.

status_message: Hearing from Dr Nicola McEwen on supranational power structures before we dive into our final session of policy motions
We're gearing up for Day 2 of our Autumn Conference in Glasgow. There will be speeches today from Jean Lambert MEP, Dr Nicola McEwen on global power, and Lothians MSP Alison Johnstone.

We've finished all our independence motions. We've voted to take a full part in the Yes Scotland campaign, as well as run our own independence campaign. Also, we voted for a Scottish currency, elected head of state, multi-option referendum & open borders

Hope you're enjoying conference. So far today we've heard from Andy Wightman on community empowerment, Patrick Harvie on the future of Scotland, and some wonderful fringe events. This afternoon sees us discussing independence
If you're coming to Glasgow, enjoy meeting up with old and new friends. See you there!

status_message:
Congratulations to Natalie Bennett and Will Duckworth on their elections as the new Leader and Deputy Leader of the Green Party of England and Wales. Here's our press release:

The Co-Convenors of the Scottish Green Party have sent their congratulations to the new leadership of the Green Party of England and Wales. Natalie Bennett was elected as Leader and Will Duckworth as Deputy Leader.

Cllr Martha Wardrop said:

"We send warm congratulations from Scotland to the new leaders of our sister party, who we know will do a brilliant job of building the profile of the Green Party. I hope that we can develop our joint efforts to get more Green Councillors elected to tackle the wide range of economic, social and environmental issues within communities."

Patrick Harvie MSP said:

"Natalie Bennett has the skill and passion to push the Green Party to new heights and to build on the superb work done by Caroline Lucas. I look forward to seeing Natalie and Will at their party conference this weekend and I hope I will be able to welcome them to Scotland in the near future. I look forward to our parties working together as we head towards the important European elections in 2014."

Aberdeen & Aberdeenshire Greens AGM & next branch meeting is Sat 22nd September, 10:30am-1pm Kintore. Please contact us for more information. We will be doing some campaign activity after the meeting. aberdeen@scottishgreens.org.uk

Over the last five years, the previous LibDem-SNP coalition in Edinburgh City Council closed 7 Primary Schools, even though they were warned that the birthrate was rising.

With a predicted increase in school rolls of 19%, the council is now having to build extensions to the remaining schools, or repurpose music and art rooms and computer suites.

Let's plan for the future, instead of stumbling around.
link_name: Greens call for long term approach to rising school rolls

Congratulations to the two Scottish Green MSPs – Alison Johnstone and Patrick Harvie – who officially took their seats in the new Scottish Parliament today.

Here's to a productive and progressive five years ahead!

Describing nuclear power as "cheap" and "low carbon" is ridiculous.  It's a dangerous technology, with no solution to its waste.  Also, a nuclear plant produces massive amounts of CO2 during its complete life cycle.

The UK government MUST reject new nuclear.  As recent tragic events in Japan prove, when nuclear goes wrong, the fallout – quite literally – does not respect national borders…

http://scot.gr/j0

status_message: RT @tweetlindsell That's me voted Green for the 1st time. When do I take delivery of my complimentary dolphin? #sp11 « http://t.co/wbZ4k08

My 2nd Vote is Green.  Why?  Because we need politicians that are for fairer taxes and against cuts, value education by keeping it free, and want to fight climate change and fuel poverty by insulating every home for free.

Greens will not be the largest party in Holyrood.  But if, like me, you want a strong Parliament challenging the government to be both honest and ambitious, please make sure you 2nd Vote Green too.

Thanks to the BBC for this great rundown on how the ballot papers work at tomorrow's election.  Public service broadcasting at its best!

http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-13131588
link_name: In pictures: Voting guide

status_message:
When the election campaign started in March, we were really pleased to have around 550 fans on Facebook.  Seven weeks on we are amazed that our support here has now more than doubled to over 1100 fans.

The growth in our support is a real indication that people believe in our sensible, fair and costed policies.  But we HAVE to turn our support here into votes.
  
Between you all, you have tens of thousands of FB friends.  To help spread the message as to why you are going to 2nd Vote Green - and encourage your friends in Scotland to do the same - we would ask that you share this picture on your personal FB wall, either this evening or first thing tomorrow.

The polls are showing Scottish Greens might have 8 MSPs in the next Parliament – our best result ever.  Spread the message as to why YOU are voting Green and maybe it could be even more!

Thank you all very much indeed.
link_name: Timeline Photos

We're not ones to self-congratulate, but a week ago we said how pleased we were that our Facebook page had reached 700 fans.  A week on, and we are at 800!

There is a real swell of support for what we are proposing. Sensible, costed policies of keeping education free, insulating every home, and using fairer taxes to invest in services.  

Thanks to everyone for supporting our vision for making a better Scotland.

We've just added a wee post encouraging people to contact broadcasters directly, to ensure that the Greens are included in the final, forthcoming party leader debates.  Could you please share it on your own walls, so as many people as possible have a chance to take action?  Many thanks!

Hello all, 
As you know, we've appealed the BBC and STV decision to exclude Greens from the TV debates. The press release from the party which sets out the arguments in favour of all parties being heard is here: http://scot.gr/g1

The broadcasters are considering the appeal right now, and they may decide as soon as tomorrow what to do. What would be really useful would be if you could email your views on this issue to them just now. It could really make the difference. 

BBC
Email the Director General's office: mark.thompson@bbc.co.uk
And please also fill in this form: https://www.bbc.co.uk/complaints/forms/

STV
Email the Viewer Enquiries section: yourview@stv.tv

Thanks a lot.
